text: One lousy Caravan isn't worth the bother. The Cathayans can keep their lives for today, and their paltry cargo.
We were short on short slaves
Fight them! Break their ancient bones and seize their wealth.
We must not be distracted from our goal. Leave them to their Unlife.
Join us. It’s not a choice.
Empower the existing army with the corpses
Hungry are they? Well in that case they can fill their bellies with our blades!
What's a few sacrifices for the many? It was probably time to cull the weak anyway – these Daemons are doing you a favour!
We will crush this host and make our consignment even more lucrative than it already is!
Hostilities and losses can be easily avoided if we just keep moving.
To end a fight as quickly and easily as possible, one needs the capacity to deal the lethal blow.
One who can endure the most dangerous and prolonged attacks has the best chance of landing a lethal counterattack.
Who are we to leave these poor Ogre mercenaries without work? Times are hard, after all!
You are strong and independent. Who needs an Ogre anyway!
The urge to throw one of the retinue into this strange formation is hard to ignore; it feels like there is great power to be had here.
Ignore it – it is best not to meddle in things we do not understand.
We can handle a few off-road chicanes – any potential losses will probably cost us less in the long run than gaining a reputation for tardiness.
We should stick to the main route and avoid exposing the cargo to any unnecessary risks.
Kill some rats and reduce the length of our journey? Sounds like a win-win!
We don’t know how many rats infest this convoy. The last thing we need is to be overwhelmed by the vermin!
The smell of gunpowder is preferable to the smell of rotting flesh. Eliminate them!
Their sacrifice allows us to continue without further losses.
Their attempts at an ambush are frankly so embarrassing it would be an insult to the Djinns to let them live.
Let them get whoever is next
They might get lucky one day. Probably not any time soon, though.
We don't need any guidance! We have an excellent sense of direction, thank you very much!
We need to reach our destination quickly; this guide had better be worth the price!
With this beast in our Caravan’s ranks, assailants will not consider us an easy target.
It would be foolish to part with some of our cargo – we have no need for this beast and can adequately protect ourselves.
We can brook no frailty in this Caravan. This is time well invested.
Training is always important, but we must not lose track of time.
We cannot risk this untested path.
Our troops can handle a few losses.

A lonely Caravan has been spotted trundling through nearby land, bearing the banners of Cathay. No doubt the products of the so-called Celestial Empire would be worth snatching for ourselves, yet such spoils are not likely to lie unguarded.\\n\\nA choice between killing or caution. It seems the answer is clear...
Caravan Encounter! A Dwarf Too Far
A wandering Caravan of Dwarfs has entered our sight. Should we attack them for a fresh new set of slaves?

Signs of a troop column have been spotted ahead. Judging by the tracks, it looks as though this force has been moving without sleep or pause. Cresting the next hill, the gleam of bone and gold can be seen throughout the army. A host of Tomb Kings, richly adorned, is marching through this area. Their destination is unclear, but their opulence is not. We could descend upon them, and claim their riches for ourselves!
It seems like there was a big battle nearby, we can take some of the remnants or use the equipment to empower the existing troops.

Traversing realms is hungry work if these Daemons we've encountered are to be believed. You could choose to sate their gluttonous appetites in the hopes of avoiding a fight. Yet, on the other hand, death would solve their hunger too…

Unfortunate wretches of many races travel the sea to gather wealth. Yet while out on assignment, even our Caravan knows not to pass up the opportunity to attain more of the "right tools" for the job, having encountered a High Elf host from whom much profit could be forcibly reaped – both in long-limbed Labourers and loot reaped from beardless corpses.
A great artefact of dark magic has come to our grasp. However, we need to decide which equipment we should empower to give the Caravan the greatest chance of successfully repelling any threats.

The strength of an Ogre is unmatched anywhere! At least, that's what this group of rotund mercenaries assured us when offering to guard our trade Caravan on its route. Their claim is ridiculous but the extra muscle wouldn't go amiss. Ogres' services, however, certainly would not come free of charge.

Without warning, a sudden chill rushes through the bones. A torrent of whispers floods the heads of the warriors, all repeating the same thing.\\n\\n[[i]]"Make a sacrifice, and overwhelming power shall be yours…"[[/i]]
The Caravan Master scouts a quicker route which would make up for the lost time. However, looking at the weather, that shortcut would result in some damaged 'goods'.
This ship is filled with rats! Unless we have dealt with them sooner or we will have to make a stop to refill our supplies. Maybe we need to track them all and kill them.

Fog has descended around our Caravan. The smell is putrid and shuffling shapes can be glimpsed in the haze. This land around us teems with their shambling forms; we have stumbled, unwittingly, into the domain of the Undead. These creatures can be confronted head-on and the wretches put down for good or, alternatively, we can order some of our number to distract them while we make our escape, though they will ultimately have no hope against the necrotic masses.

Stealth is possibly not the strong suit of our would-be ambushers, who visibly await our Caravan from some rather questionable 'hiding' places. We could avoid them easily, of course, but it almost seems a disservice not to show them what a true ambush looks like...

A guide has tracked down our Caravan, offering to lead the way to our destination in exchange for a reasonable donation to his pockets. His price is frankly extortionate, but as they say in business, time is of the essence.

A cacophony of roars and feral shrieks rings out ahead of your Caravan – a Dark Elf Beastmaster approaches! By the look of his shackled beasts, he is recently returned from an expedition into Norsca and poses little threat, his retinue of hunters visibly weary and battered from their run-ins with the Northmen and critters of the tundra. With a tired Druchii sneer, he offers the Caravan one of his creatures in exchange for some slaves. Though we care little for the Dark Elf’s plight, such a beast could be useful against future threats.

The day may have just begun, but one of the scouts has already spotted a wide, flat, stone platform in an isolated area. A series of eight steps leads to an eight-sided arena, with grooves carved in the floor to drain the blood spilled. Unmistakably, this is a Khornate combat shrine: the perfect location to tutor troops and beat the weakness out of them.
Caravan Encounter! The Path of Storms
A strong current is in front of our eyes. We can traverse this rough current and reach our destination sooner, but it may take the lives of some of our weaker personnel.
Caravan Encounter! Tribute to the Phoenix King
Caravan Encounter! The Mountain Folks Caravan
Caravan Encounter! The Heirs of Mourkain
Caravan Encounter! A Paramour in Pavona
Caravan Encounter! One Man’s Treasure is Another Gnoblar’s Treasure
Caravan Encounter! Walk Like a Nehekharan
Caravan Encounter! A Tithe of Bone
Caravan Encounter! Ambushed by Rope Djinns!
One of your caravans has crossed a Tomb King crypt, one owned by a dynasty that despises your caravans' objective. They demand all portions of your caravan's goods.

Along the road, some of your caravaneers are ambushed, the sky being blotted out with smoke and chittering filling the air. They offer usage of their Underways to speed up your journey, if only for 1300 gold and some of your goods.

Your caravan is halted by a far-flung Black Ark, seemingly here for piracy. Eyeing your slaves, and desperate for anything, they make a deal. They will take some of your slaves, and you will take some of their finest soldiers.

It is no secret that the southern seas are home to many hidden coves and islands where the pirates of Sartosa like to hide their booty. As it happens you spot a pirate crew digging around on a shore not too far away from you. Fighting them might not be part of your route but it might get you whatever they are looking for…

The High Elves are infamous for thinking of themselves as the guardians of the world, this part included. A force sent from Ulthuan to one of their far-flung colonies happens upon your caravan and makes it very clear that you are to pay a tax to the Phoenix court for conducting trade here. Of course, some handlers would have to be assigned to you for the rest of your journeys too to keep you “safe”. They don’t seem to give us much of a choice...
Your caravan stops some distance from a gigantic lamp-shaped tree. Is it merely a mirage? Surely a foreboding one, and right in the middle of the only viable path. What should we do?

Our Caravan has come upon a minor Bretonnian Errantry led by a Noble bearing the familial name of one of the original Bretonnian Crusaders who invaded our shores! We have a chance to avenge our Ancestors deaths by the hands of these Savages or we can continue on our path.

Our Caravan has been halted by a force of High Elves who demand we pay the customary Tribute to the Phoenix King, the Elves think these trade-routes are their property and are citing all sorts of ancient treaties to prove their claim.

Our Caravans are used to dealing with Corsairs from our own shores, but this time some intrepid Corsair Captain has organised a large force to halt our progress and demands we hand over tribute to be allowed safe passage.

We have stumbled upon a band of Soldiers of Fortune from the Northern Empire. While their customs and beliefs are weird, especially their dogmatic belief in their man god ‘Sigmar’, they can be reliable soldiers. Let's hope they learn to wash themselves properly while in our employ if we hire them.

We spotted a smoke column in the distance, upon further inspection we noticed that it was moving, specifically it is moving towards us; it’s a Chaos Dwarf convoy, led by a priest of Hashut, upon their approach, they make their intentions clear: they are looking to trade, and they won't take no for an answer.

As we track across the lands near the mountains you spotted a Dwarfen caravan. Upon the approach one Thane approached and wishes to follow along with our caravan because of grudges against members of his current group. But the sharp eyes amongst you also notice that the caravan also brings with them plenty of treasure, and for those with a thirst for more gold this is easy pickings.

As our caravan stops for the night at a shady oasis they encounter a tribe of the nomadic Strigany people. These folk ply the roads same as us but their customs are odd to say the least. The head of the tribe, a wise-woman bedecked in patchwork fabrics and fetishes of bone, meets with our caravan leader and offers to guide us to a shortcut through these dangerous lands in exchange for some of our cargo.

Strange mists surround our caravan as we are forced to push the wagons through a muddy mire. The beasts of burden are ill at ease as bloated flies hover over us like buzzards circling a desert meal and the thick, humid air makes each laboured breath harder to endure. Just when we thought things couldn’t get any worse, a shrill cry is heard over the din of swamplife and a ululating horde of one-eyed monsters emerge from the waters with crude weapons and vile magic in hand.

It is said that our caravan leader is a paramour of the famed Princess of Pavona herself, Lucrezzia Belladonna. After their last meeting she promised a lavish gift in the future and now a delegation of mercenaries from Pavona has found our caravan and they present a gift from their employer.

While travelling on the road our caravan spots a lumbering beast hauling a ramshackle wagon crewed by a scrawny bunch of Gnoblars. The wagon pulls alongside of us and the head of this odd band, a spectacled Gnoblar wearing a turban of Arabyan fashion, speaks to our caravan leader of his journeys throughout these lands. He eyes our cargo the entire time and he asks for some of it to fund his latest invention, the Gnoblar Gnose Gnourisher. He offers you the services of his guards in return for your shiny scrap.

While travelling along the rolling dunes of Nehekhara our caravan chances upon a tomb that has been uncovered by the desert winds. The tomb appears to be untouched by time and ripe for the picking. Once inside, the men encounter a regally dressed skeleton who claims to be a prince and that our caravan leader is his long lost king. The skeleton promises to guard his “king” for eternity but all the men see are the riches that were buried here alongside the prince.

As our caravan traverses past a once empty ruin they notice that there is a gleaming light far down the road. The caravan approaches this light but it soon resolves into the image of an army on the march. Rank upon rank of skeletons march in perfect lockstep and hulking beasts of bone are spotted behind them. It appears they are marching this way and they most definitely see the caravan.

While travelling through foreign lands, your caravan encounters a local force equipped with fine blades of ensorcelled Arabyan steel. Very familiar blades, as a matter of fact. Upon inquiring about the situation, you discover that these blades were recovered from an Arabyan shipwreck their master recently looted. One of your merchant vessels, it seems, lost at sea not too long ago. By rights, these blades are yours.

We hear our fellow Arabyan caravan before we see it, great drums pounding on the backs of elephants, oud lutes plucking sweet notes, and the sound of Arabyan marching songs splitting the air. The caravan master scoffs, for surely this lesser caravan cannot match our wealth and glory. But then we see them, riders on Flying Carpets! Outrageous! How dare this lesser caravan have such prestigious allies?!

As we come to a desert outpost, we see a terrible sight. The guards are all missing, and blood is everywhere! As we search the outpost to discover what could have caused such a tragedy, the men shout in alarm! A swarm of furious Rope Djinns, angered at having been bound in such a manner, ready themselves to attack!
“Whatever they are digging for might fetch a nice price at the marketplace…”
“How about we show them who really owns this land?”
Rub the Tree are you daft? There shall be no lamp unrubbed on my path.
We're sorry but at the moment we're a bit short on slaves
“The extra hand is nice but the gold is nicer.”
“How would you like to work for me?”
Rob the Scrapper and claim his scrap for yourself
“I think I’ll just take your scrap.”
Demand the return of the weapons
Demand the return of the weapons
Punish the rival caravan for their insolence
These fools dare have better steeds than us?! We must attack these upstarts and take their Flying Carpets for ourselves!

We ready ourselves for a battle, but it's over too quickly. The ropes are blurs of carnage, and a whole unit is slaughtered before we flee the outpost! At least the men who survive are hardened by the experience.
May the Djinns never guide us along that path again.
We do not know who these strange people are, but their offer is kind.
They barter well for torturers. We accept.
“Though it never feels good to validate haughty elves, help is always needed… ”
This is obviously a test. And I am a generous man.
This Noble is not their Ancestor.
They drive a hard bargain, but we really don't want to anger them
“Join us. We can always use an extra short hand.”
“Leave the wagons and take all you can carry.”
And inform them where they can acquire more
Any caravan master wealthy enough to afford such luxury will know the value of our cargo. We'll use it to buy ALL his carpets, rather than simply scavenging whatever's left after a battle.
Retreat and bind them from afar!
We retreat before the Rope Djinns attack, and our Magicians begin the rituals of binding. This will take some time...
